newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka's DFCC plans expansion.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka's DFCC plans expansion.

text.p: Sri Lanka's largest financial institution, the Development Finance Corp of Ceylon, transformed itself into a bank on Wednesday and said it planned to expand.

Announcing the change and a new identity -- DFCC Bank -- general manager and chief executive Moksevi Prelis told Reuters the group's operations had turned around and would make increased profits in the current financial year.
He said the bank's fortunes had improved with a recent upturn in the Sri Lankan economy, which had boosted industrial investment in the Indian Ocean island and demand for credit.
"This year will certainly be better than last year," Prelis said in an interview. "We can already see the signs."

On Tuesday, DFCC reported a net profit of 119 million rupees ($2 million) for its first quarter to June 30, up 29 percent year-on-year. The improvement was achieved on a quarterly income of 643 million rupees, against 554 million rupees the year before.

DFCC deputy general manager for finance Subramaniam Nagarajah said the institution had faced a difficult year in 1996/97, partly due to a nationwide drought, which led to lengthy power cuts across industry.
Asked if DFCC could match the 1995/96 total net profit of 590 million rupees, Nagarajah replied: "I would say we will strive to better it."

Prelis said the bank would benefit from a recovery in the Sri Lankan economy, which is expected by economists to bounce back to around six percent gross domestic product (GDP) growth this year after a slowdown to 3.8 percent in 1996.
But he said the country's 14-year-old ethnic war, in which the government has been battling separatists of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), still hampered the economy.
The LTTE is fighting for a homeland for the minority Tamil population in the island's north and east.

"If some settlement of this war takes place, we have no doubt that the country will boom and all of us will thrive," Perlis said. "Sri Lanka is well placed if that happens to play a major role in South Asia. DFCC will be part of that boom."

Prelis said the group, a specialist bank under legislation passed this week, would expand in several areas such as treasury operations, stockbroking and investment banking, possibly in alliance with other local or foreign banks.
He said Sri Lanka was likely to see mergers and acquisitions in the banking and finance sector over the next few years, creating fewer but bigger bank groups.
Sri Lanka now has more than 25 banks and a range of smaller finance houses dealing with specialist lending for a largely rural population of just over 18 million.
"The proliferation of small financial institutions is not a healthy development because they are too small. They will have to amalgamate or merge to be good for this sector," he said.
Prelis said he could envisage a scenario in the future where DFCC Bank would tie up with the state-owned Sri Lanka Insurance Corp and with Sri Lanka's Commercial Bank.
He said DFCC was continuing to discuss with British bank Standard Chartered Plc the possibility of buying part of its stake in the local Commercial Bank.
Such a tie-up could produce useful synergies and help both banks offer better service to their clients, he said.
"We have got the permission of the Central Bank for taking a major portion of Commercial Bank. We may form a strategic alliance with Commercial Bank in future," he said.
($1=58.7 rupees)
